description: From Middle English mynder, mendowre (“one who has a good memory; bears in mind; watches over; a keeper”); equivalent to mind +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: One who minds, tends, or watches something such as a child, a machine, or cattle; a keeper.

A monitor assigned by the authorities to someone, such as a foreign visitor (to exercise control over their contacts with the populace) or a journalist or someone who is speaking to journalists (to monitor and control what they say).
examples: The twenty-eight journalists who sailed with the task force were accompanied by seven censors or 'minders' from the MoD, as well as by military press officers attached to each unit.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) One who is taken care of, such as a pauper child in the care of private person; a ward.
